Title: Leisure Cycle to Altrincham - Waterways and Mosslands Loop
Summary:
Mark the start of British Summer Time with a leisurely Sunday ride from Manchester city centre following the Bridgewater Canal and River Mersey, passing through the Trafford Millennium Woodland and Carrington Moss by MUFC's training ground, before reaching Broadheath in Altrincham and returning to our starting point along the canal
This is a scenic, mainly traffic free ride along canal towpaths and cycleways including a section of the Trans Pennine Trail. There are various places to stop for refreshments en route, including the popular Riverbank Coffee on the banks of the River Mersey.
New riders are most welcome!
Please note that clocks go forward 1 hr the previous night. The start time is slightly later than normal to accommodate adjusting to the new time.
Ride Overview:
Distance:
Approx. 20 miles
Pace
: Leisurely, around 8–10 mph with stops. No one will get left behind.
Ascent:
215 ft in total (mostly flat with a few gentle inclines)
Surface:
a mixture of canal towpaths, cycleways and unpaved paths which may be uneven in places, with minimal on road. Carrington Moss may be a bit muddy after rain
Estimated ride time:
around 3 hours of cycling plus a 30-minute café stop
Suitable for most levels of fitness and anyone looking for a leisurely social ride
Essentials to Bring:
A roadworthy bike:
Hybrid, gravel, or mountain bikes are best suited to this ride due to uneven towpaths and some unsurfaced tracks. A road bike should be fine but there are a few short bumpy sections where it might be advisable to dismount and walk.
Helmet:
required for all OutdoorLads cycling events
Suitable clothing including a waterproof. Layers are recommended.
Spare inner tube or puncture kit
Water and any snacks you need
Card/cash for the café stop
Don't forget your bike lock if you have one.
Photo credits: All photos are property of the event leader and used with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: A leisurely cycle ride

Title: Leisurely Walks around Lairg, Sutherland
Summary:
This event offers a bit of a smorgasbord of short, leisurely walks. You can choose on the day to do just one or more. All four on offer total 11.5km or 7 miles. And we have an excellent cafe / restaurant on the lochside to enjoy refreshments whilst in Lairg.
The walks offer:
beautiful natural woodland
a fine loch dam
loch shore and ponds
a hill top viewing point (only 60m of ascent!)
plenty of archaeological remains including iron age brochs, hut circles, a chambered cairn believed to be a 5000 year old burial mound
powerful falls, not for their height but for their sheer water power
riverside walking
And to round things off, we can visit The Pier for refreshments (great cakes and other stuff!!).
NB There may be a parking charge for the Falls.
Dogs are welcome but need to be kept under close control.
Photos :
Taken by Rob Mitchell and Mark Dooley and used with permission.

chat

groups and bookmark our upcoming events list via our
Scottish Calendar
.
Difficulty & Distance: Medium if you do all 4 walks, may be easier if you choose fewer!

Title: BIRMINGHAM Indoor Climbing - MONDAY - Experienced
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for an evening of indoor climbing & bouldering at Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre.
"EXPERIENCED" in this instance is those that have previously climbed & can answer YES to all three of these questions:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie in to a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly & confidently?
Please ensure you only sign up for this event if you
satisfy all three of the prerequisites as an experienced (independent) climber!
Never climbed before? Need a refresher on the basics? Answered NO to any of the three questions above? You will need to
attend a beginners (supervised) event
instead, where we will happily sign you in to be supervised (two people per leader maximum), show you the ropes & teach you everything you need to know to climb safely!  Beginner (supervised) events are offered every two weeks only; this enables the event leader to climb too.
Bouldering
- Whilst most of us do roped climbing, if you prefer to do bouldering, you can sign yourself in & go bouldering (unsupervised) instead of, or as well as, roped climbing. Please meet the leader & the group at the start though; some others might wish to do bouldering too!
Please note that we will not teach lead climbing or lead belaying on this event -
we would suggest having some
lessons in Lead Climbing
by a qualified member of staff if this is something you're interested in pursuing!
Whilst this event finishes at 8pm, the centre is open until 10pm if you wish to continue climbing for longer!
If you are subsequently unable to attend, please cancel off the event as 'no-shows' are frustrating for the leader & other attendees.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.
Climbing
- Unlike Indoor Bouldering there is a certain amount of skill to be mastered, such as tying in knots & belaying a partner, as well as the climbs being higher than in bouldering. If you are new to climbing or would like a refresher, then this is just for you!! If you’ve climbed before, can safely tie into a harness & can competently belay, then there’s plenty of choices of top-rope & lead climbing on offer here.
Bouldering
- Instead of tackling long high routes, the 'problems' (as they are referred to) are shorter & focus on technique, balance, body positioning & sometimes power. With the different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, so it’s excellent (but not necessarily easier) for newcomers.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
has more than 75 lines with over 300 routes, set through some spectacular ground including its notorious 'stalactite'. It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.
You MUST register via this event page before coming to the centre!

climbing shoes (

Title: Nottingham Bouldering - MONDAY - Beginners Welcome
Summary:
Swap trainers for climbing shoes and join OutdoorLads for an evening of INDOOR BOULDERING at Nottingham’s newest bouldering venue
NOTE: If you are climbing with us for the first time
, either as an experienced climber or beginner, please send a note to the
Event Leader
telling them about your experience and goals. There is a limit to the number of beginners that we can accommodate at each session. Each beginner needs to be supervised so we need to ensure there are enough experienced climbers to help you out. Climbing is great fun! It's a fab workout, in a social environment, and anyone can do it! Give it a go!
What is Bouldering?
It's a form of climbing where instead of long high routes, the 'problems' tend to be shorter and focus on technique, balance, body positioning and sometimes power. Because of this different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, harnesses and belaying, which makes it an excellent activity for newcomers to the sport. No wonder it's often regarded as the 'purest' form of climbing.
If you're a seasoned climber you won't need convincing about the benefits of bouldering, but for those who've never climbed more than a staircase, the benefits are wide ranging: from the physical - improved strength, tone, balance, power and coordination; mental - problem solving, focus, concentration and body awareness; to the emotional - relaxation, a sense of achievement and a feeling that mind and body are working together perfectly ('feeling psyched'). On top of all this, bouldering tends to be a very social sport where you can hang out with mates and each have a go as you feel regardless of what level you climb at.
I'm new to Bouldering - can I come along?
If you have never tried bouldering before it is recommended that you have a guided session from the event leader, who will go through everything you will need to know to boulder safely before joining in with the rest of the group.
I've been Bouldering before?
As above, everyone attending the event  must abide by the centre's T&Cs etc. As an experienced boulderer you are responsible for your own safety, actions and involvement at all times. As such, you should use your own judgement in taking up advice given either by OutdoorLads Volunteers or other experienced climbers.
To climb at Nottingham Climbing Centre you will need to:
-     Complete a climbing waiver for the centre (please arrive early to do this the first time, or better still complete it online before you arrive.) You can find the
link
to the waiver and bouldering safety video
here
on Nottingham Climbing Centre's website.
-     Pay the Lifetime Registration Fee - £6.00
-     Pay an Entry Fee directly to the climbing centre - £9.50 (ensure you mention ODL)
-     Hire shoes (if you don’t have your own) - £3.50*
*Equipment hire charges will be waived for your first visit to the centre!
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
IMPORTANT! - Participation Statement
You MUST complete a
Participation Statement
,
in addition
to booking your event space before attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Please note that every person participating should be aware of (and accept) that those members perceived as ‘in charge’ or leading the event are not necessarily qualified, do not need to be qualified, and are not regarded by OutdoorLads, or themselves as ‘technical experts’ but are amateur climbers with some experience and who are happy to impart their knowledge. Any advice given should be considered with this in mind by the recipient.
All those attending the event must also be aware of the centre's own terms and conditions of participation and abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre’s staff. Everyone must also take responsibility for their own safety while participating in Indoor climbing events.
Photos:
All images supplied by event leaders and used by OutdoorLads with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Suitable for all abilities. If you're new to bouldering, just let the event leader know and we'll get you started!

Title: NOTTINGHAM Indoor Climbing – THURSDAY – Beginners Welcome
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads at Nottingham Climbing Centre
Climbing evenings are held regularly and we tend to go to the local pub – The Lion for refreshments and a social gathering afterwards where they have a wide variety of beverages both alcoholic and non-alcoholic.
NOTE: If you are climbing with us for the first time
, either as an experienced climber or beginner, please send a note to the
Event Leader
telling them about your experience and goals. There is a limit to the number of beginners that we can accommodate at each session. Each beginner needs to be supervised so we need to ensure there are enough experienced climbers to help you out. Climbing is great fun! It's a fab workout, in a social environment, and anyone can do it! Give it a go!
Nottingham Climbing Centre
Nottingham Climbing Centre is equipped with walls and routes to suit all skill levels and groups of climbers, whether you are a novice looking to try climbing for the first time, or an experienced lead climber, you’ll find an area to challenge you. With 28 Top Ropes routes available as well as 24 Lines of Lead climbing for the more advanced individuals. In addition, 6 auto-belays are available, so there is always the opportunity to climb, even if the numbers don’t match up. The available bouldering walls also provide that extra physical and mental challenge for those looking for something slightly different from rope work. Both Bouldering and Rope Climbing routes range from 4a – 8a.
I'm new to Climbing - can I come along?
If you've never climbed before or need a refresher, the leader will sign you into the climbing centre as a
supervised climber
so that you can come and give it a try (it can be helpful to message the leader to let them know). If you enjoy your climbing experience, and would like to come climbing more regularly, we will also happily show you the ropes and teach you everything you need to know to climb safely.
Do I need to be Supervised as a Climber?
If you answer
NO
to any of the following three questions, then you will need to arrange to be supervised. If you can answer YES to all these questions, you can sign up to this event as normal:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie yourself to the end of a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly and confidently?
To come along, you will need to register via this event page and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the climbing centre when you arrive, please see their
website
for up-to-date prices. We ask that all members sign up through the event page to make sure the event leader has all information of the members attending.
To climb at Nottingham Climbing Centre you will need to:
-     Complete a climbing waiver for the centre (please arrive early to do this the first time, or better still complete it online before you arrive)
-     Pay the Lifetime Registration Fee - £6.00
-     Pay an Entry Fee directly to the climbing centre - £9.50 (ensure you mention ODL)
-     Hire shoes (if you don’t have your own) - £3.50*
-     Hire a harness (again, if you don’t have your own) - £3.50*
-     Hire shoes and harness - £6.00*
*Equipment hire charges will be waived for your first visit to the centre!
Can I just come along and boulder?
Absolutely! Most of us do roped climbing, but if you prefer bouldering, you can sign yourself in and do it, as long as you can fill in the climbing centre's form correctly, watch their
safety video
and can answer the simple safety questions at reception on your first visit. Meet the group at the start; some others might be bouldering. We will make sure we come and find you when we have our tea break!
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
IMPORTANT! - Participation Statement
You MUST complete a
Participation Statement
, in addition to booking your event space before attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Anyone with COVID-19 symptoms, even if they are extremely mild, or who has recently tested positive for Covid-19, is asked not to attend.
Photos:
All images supplied by event leaders and used by OutdoorLads with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Beginners welcome.

Title: Sculpture stroll at YSP
Summary:
Join me for a leisurely stroll around the
Yorkshire Sculpture Park
in West Bretton.
A ticket is required
to attend this event. Prices are listed on this
page
. Your ticket includes car parking for those driving. I would strongly encourage you to purchase your ticket online in advance.
There is a lot to see, so there are plenty of options, whatever the weather. The longest route is around 6 miles, but there are shorter options for those who prefer.
I really enjoyed the
William Kentridge: The Pull of Gravity
exhibition on my recent visit. This is staged in the underground gallery and outdoors.
There are several new exhibitions coming up that should be ready by the time of our visit. These include:
Andi Walker: Wrapped in Cold Hard Comfort
Louise Lockhart: Cake Crumbs and Lemonade
LR Vandy: Rise
Dogs: Well-behaved, under control dogs are welcome at this event. However, note that when I visited, a couple of specific areas were not permitting dogs to prevent bird flu.
Dogs should be kept on a lead whenever signposted, whenever we are in the vicinity of livestock, and at the event leader's request. Some stretches of this walk include sheep roaming. You'll need to make sure you're carrying sufficient extra water for your four-legged friend. We will meet natural water on parts of the walk. If you're unsure, contact the leader for guidance.
If the event is fully booked: Please join the wait list as people frequently drop out during the week before an event, and you are likely to get a place on the walk.
If this is your first OutdoorLads walk event, we’ll make sure you feel welcome. Please
check out the My First Event page
, and don’t hesitate to drop me a message if you have questions or want to know more about this walk.
Image/photo credits:  All leader's own images - with permission for OutdoorLads to use.
Difficulty & Distance: Leisurely stroll around parkland, with a few slight inclines.

Title: South from the Mouth of the Tees SPRING RESCHEDULED DATE
Summary:
Fancy a refreshing easier stroll in the early spring in the  Cleveland/North Yorkshire area?  Well come over and walk away the blues on the Yorkshire beaches in the company of OutdoorLads.
This walk is an easy linear route outing along the beach making use of the local train service to return
The views on the outward leg impress as the land to the south rises from the sea in impressive sandstone cliffs, further along this section of the coast to Skinningrove are the highest cliffs on the east coast of England.
There is an opportunity to visit a ruined old church ruin to seek out the curious graves of the many who perished in the stormy waters and the pirate skull and cross bones etched on weathered grave stones.
The beaches visited on the walk at low tide are wide and easily shared with the horse riders, joggers and dog walkers.  There will be a pause at a midway point for the opportunity to go for food and a warm drink.
The destination is the charming resort of Saltburn-By-The-Sea and we will spend plenty of time here to walk to the end of the pier continue to Old Saltburn.
We will then either use the cliff lift to reach the higher level paths if open on the edge of the town and after a stop for photographs and pause at a nice bar before catching the train back to the start.
Photo Credits: The photographs used on this event page have been taken by OutdoorsLads leaders and permission to use in this publication and any future event pages or other releases.
Difficulty & Distance: 10.9km/6.8 miles one steep short climb

Title: Low Force and Middleton in Teesdale circular
Summary:
Total distance about 21.7kms (approx. 13.5 miles) with 400m (1,300 feet) ascent throughout. Approximately 5 1/2 hours, including lunch.
This walk includes sections that are relatively flat (riverside), a fairly challenging ascent, hillside with panoramic views, and the delightful town of Middleton-in-Teesdale. Although it is long and in places, strenuous, it's well worth the effort.
Starting from the High Force Hotel, we descend towards the River Tees. We cross the river and follow its course past the stunning Low Force waterfall. We then cross the river again via a narrow suspension bridge to reach Bowlees. This is where the ascent begins.
The next section of the walk passes through several farms, before crossing open hillside. As we begin to descend, we pass through woodland and follow Hudeshope Beck towards Middleton-in-Teesdale.
We cross the town, and there are several places to purchase refreshments, if required. We then cross the River Tees again, before following it's course back to the start point. This does mean repeating a small section of the riverside that we covered in the morning.
After the walk, there will be an optional trip to The High Force Hotel in Forest in Teesdale for anyone who would like a drink.
Please note that this walk does NOT include High Force waterfall. If you wish to visit this, tickets cost £3.95 for adults. As winter access is 10am-3pm, you would need to visit before the 10:30 am walk start time. You can find further information on the
Raby website
.
Dogs: Well-behaved, under control dogs are welcome at this event.
Dogs should be kept on a lead whenever signposted, whenever we are in the vicinity of livestock, and at the event leader's request. Many stretches of this walk include sheep roaming. I would also note that there are quite a few up-and-over wall stiles towards the end of the walk, so you get a bit of an upper-body workout lifting your dogs over them. You'll need to make sure you're carrying sufficient extra water for your four-legged friend. We will meet natural water on parts of the walk. If you're unsure, contact the leader for guidance.
If the event is fully booked:
Please join the wait list as people frequently drop out during the week before an event, and you are likely to get a place on the walk.
If this is your first OutdoorLads walk event,
we’ll make sure you feel welcome. Please
check out the My First Event page
, and don’t hesitate to drop me a message if you have questions or want to know more about this walk.
Image/photo credits:
All leader's own images - with permission for OutdoorLads to use.
Difficulty & Distance: Moderate towards Very Hard, depending on your level of fitness

Title: Bouldering MANCHESTER - Beginners welcome
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads For an Evening of INDOOR BOULDERING in Manchester!
This event is intended as a safe space for the LGBTQ+ community; everyone will be warmly welcomed
Bouldering is a form of climbing that focuses on shorter "problems" emphasising technique, balance, body positioning, and sometimes power, rather than long, high routes. Without the need for ropes, harnesses, and belaying, bouldering is an accessible activity for newcomers and is often considered the "purest" form of climbing.
Bouldering offers a wide range of benefits, including:
Physical:
Improved strength, tone, balance, power, and coordination.
Mental:
Enhanced problem-solving, focus, concentration, and body awareness.
Emotional:
Relaxation, a sense of achievement, and a feeling of mind-body connection.
Bouldering is also a fantastic way to meet new people and build lasting friendships, as it's an inherently social sport where climbers share tips and strategies to conquer the routes.
New to Bouldering?
If you're new to bouldering, it is recommended that you have a guided session from the event leader to learn the basics of safe bouldering. The leader can then introduce you to the rest of the group where you can refine your newly learnt skills in a social environment.
Experienced Boulderer?
If you’re new to climbing with ODL, the leader will help to introduce you to the rest of the group so you can explore the centre together.
You are responsible for your own safety and actions while bouldering. Please use your own judgement when accepting advice from OutdoorLads Volunteers or other experienced climbers, regardless of your bouldering experience.
Ready to boulder?
You will need to sign up on the ODL event page. We would ask you to do this each time so that the leader has access to important information
If you are not already registered with Rock Over Climbing, please do so
here
to save time when you arrive. You only need to do this once.
When you arrive at the centre you will need to pay for entry and hire climbing shoes if you don't own a pair. ODL members benefit from the concessionary rate so please mention this when paying.
Get bouldering! You’ll find most of the group already bouldering so feel free to join them. If you’re new to bouldering with ODL, the leader will be looking out for you so if you spot them, please go speak with them first.
Any questions?
If you have any questions, please contact the leader directly.
Photos : Copyright granted to OutdoorLads by
Sieh
and joenellist.
Difficulty & Distance: Suitable for all abilities. If you're new to bouldering, just let the event leader know and we'll get you started!

Title: Leeds Country Way from Thorner
Summary:
Friday is a lovely day to get out for a local walk. There are fewer people around and it’s easier to get parking.
This walk starts in Thorner, east of Leeds. We will mostly walk  through fields, tracks and old railway lines, all flat, no hills.
The walk starts at 10:30am, but we will be having a midmorning and lunch break. I also like to stop and look at things along the way whether it is wildlife or unusual rock formations.
Well behaved dogs are welcome on this event. Please keep your dog on a lead and under control at all times.
Image credits : All images provided by the walk leader. OutdoorLads has permission to use them.
Difficulty & Distance: Flat, no hills

Title: Explore the Inns and Outs of Surgeons, Lawyers and Rogues
Summary:
THIS WALK IS ON A FRIDAY
This easy linear walk combines cultural sights and visits:
Hunterian Museum – art and science of surgery with some fascinating exhibits.
Inns of Court at Lincoln’s Inn, Gray's Inn and Middle/Inner Temples.
St Bride’s - known as the journalist’s or wedding cake church.
2 Temple Place including its annual art exhibition.
The walk is inspired by my days as a young and eager legal beagle around Holborn, long long ago…
We will visit sights around Holborn, Chancery and Fleet Street, and stop for stories following the footsteps of lawyers, surgeons and journalists.
For the indoor sights, I’ll explain the highlights and we will have time to explore independently. Each sight has free entry. We’ll spend up to 1 hour at each of the Hunterian Museum and 2 Temple Place.
Afterwards, please feel free to join for optional drinks at the Old Bank of England.
Don't waste that space!
The maximum group size is 15 for this event. This is due to it being an urban walk and bookings have been made for the indoor attractions.
Please only book if you know you can make it. If your plans change please free up the space for someone else.
Hunterian Museum
This is the headquarters of the Royal College of Surgeons, and the museum was reopened in 2023 following a £4.6m redevelopment. It tells the story of the history of surgery to the present day, and you’ll see England’s largest public display of human anatomy. We will have time to visit properly and are booked in.
The Inns of Court
All barristers must belong to an Inn of Court, and the plan is to walk through all four of them - Lincoln’s Inn, Gray’s Inn, Middle and Inner Temples. This is why the walk is on a weekday. We won’t be able to visit the chapels/great halls, but will pass the impressive barristers’ chambers and gardens, which have the feel of historical Oxbridge colleges.
Chancery Lane and Fleet Street
There will be plenty of zig-zagging through the alleys and courtyards of legal London. We should be able to pass St Ethelburga’s Chapel, the old red brick Victorian Gothic Prudential Building and Dr Johnson’s House, where he compiled the Dictionary of the English Language. Fleet Street is the original home of London printing and the press.
St Bride’s Church
The reconstructed Christopher Wren church is known as the journalists’ church. Its spire may have inspired traditional tiered wedding cakes, and is only exceeded by St Paul’s Cathedral in the City. We may be able to see the memorial to the first known victim of Jack the Ripper and visit the crypt with its Roman pavement.
Two Temple Place
Built for Lord Astor (who was one of the richest men in the world) as his office around 1895, with neo-Gothic wooden carvings and windows. It opens for an annual exhibition. This year’s is “Weight of Being: Vulnerability, Resilience and Mental Health in Art” which we are booked in for and will visit.
—-
Dogs - sorry, no dogs are permitted at these sights.
Toilets at each indoor sightseeing stop.
The
route
can be seen on the
OS Map -
Click here
- which is included for guidance only.
New Members
New members are very welcome. Please message me if you have any questions or concerns before the day.
Whilst we are a very open and welcoming group, if you wish, we may be able to organise an existing member to buddy up with you before or on the day. Do also feel free to arrive early as I’m always around much earlier than the start time.
All leader's own images - with permission for OutdoorLads to use and reuse
Difficulty & Distance: 3.7 miles - flat walk with sightseeing and visits to indoor attractions

Title: 1000m Lords Over Thor
Summary:
My Lord! Your challenge is to conquer the peaks of the Manifold Valley, adding up to 1000 metres of ascent over the day. Along the way you will see much superb scenery of the White Peak, limestone shining in the spring light. The challenge culminates above Thor's cave, marking your Lordship over the whole valley!
This difficult hill route follows many steep slopes, making use of access land and permissive paths at times, as well as scrambly banks, so you will need to be comfortable with this kind of walk. We aim to cover the three tops of Wetton Hill, (319m 355m 328m), Ecton Hill (369m), Ecton South top (360m), Dale above Sugar Load (325m), Ossoms Hill (334m) and Thor's Height (294m). The rewards for this are that you will have accomplished an amazing challenge and experienced some unbeatable and incredible views of Thor's cave and the Manifold Valley. The walk southwards on a hidden route towards the impending Thor's cave is particularly spectacular.
Ecton Hill at the north end of our route was the centre of historic copper mines and a wealthy earner for local miners. There are information boards near the mine remains. We'll also see the small cave at Wettonmill, where there is a tearoom, which we will pass mid-afternoon.
From Ossom's Hill we head onward with giant Thor looming ahead, cross the Manifold river and head up a path with a long flight of steps. The cave itself is huge, slippy and scrambly. After the cave, we will go further to circle the giant's lair and come out on top, above the cave, for all round views of the valley.
This is as difficult as hill walks get and is pretty much the same as a mountain walk, and certainly good preparation for one, We may adjust the walk according to weather conditions, and there will be an opportunity to miss a peak if you're tired, but please come ready for a challenge. A recent OutdoorLads hill walk would be excellent preparation!
If bad weather, we may shorten the route to 500m ascent, but will still include Thor's cave. Note that if you just wanted to see Thor's cave without the rest of the challenge, you might be better choosing a hillwalk focused on that alone, which is offered by OutdoorLads leaders regularly, if not often.
Well behaved dogs who are fit enough to manage this challenge are welcome to accompany us on this walk.
Note:
If there are no places left on this event, join the waiting list, as people frequently drop out during the week before an event, and you are likely to get a place.

Pictures: taken by Outdoorlads members, free to reuse.
Difficulty & Distance: 1000m ascent over around 10.5miles  / 17km with some steep terrain

Title: Hull parkrun
Summary:
Joining us for the Hull Social or just in the area anyway?  Why not join OutdoorLads at Hull parkrun?
This is one of a number of events we have organised over the weekend of the
Hull Social
.
If you are planning to attend the walk or bouldering event today, we have allowed sufficient time to get to either of these once you have completed the run
About parkrun
While parkrun is a public event, if joining as part of OutdoorLads please do join this event page (and drop off it if you can no longer attend) so the leader knows who to expect and who to inform if there is a change of plans..
The course is 5000m (5km) long. This has been accurately measured by parkrun with a professional measuring wheel. It's run on paths and grass, although some sections of the course do accumulate mud, leaves and puddles after rain.  Dependent on availability, marshals will be at key sections of the course, or signs will be in place.
The important bit... This is about personal goals. You run/walk at your own pace, don't be scared that you may be slower than other people. Some walk, some run, some jog, some do a combination of all three.
To take part in a parkrun and get your official time,
you will need to have
registered
to receive your all important barcode
.
You will need to bring this barcode with you either printed or on your phone.
Parkrun events are run nationwide and indeed internationally, so once you're signed up you can attend anywhere.  If you don't have a barcode you can still run but won't get a time.
Please see under Location for meeting plans.
The event link is here:
https://www.parkrun.org.uk/hull/
Dogs
parkrun allow one dog per person on a short lead (not extending).  Running with more than one dog, extending leads or waist leads are not permitted at parkrun events.  As a third party event, OutdoorLads does not have any control over this.
OutdoorLads Running Groups
If you want to join the Outdoorlads' national group on the parkrun website, on your parkrun account select Profile, then groups and type "Outdoorlads (UK)" and click the Join button.
You may also wish to sign up to the
Strava OutdoorLads running club:
https://www.strava.com/clubs/439735
Photos by an OutdoorLads leader (OutdoorWill) and used with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Run or walk at your own pace

Title: London Indoor Climbing Evening - All abilities- Beginners welcome
Summary:
Come join OutdoorLads for indoor climbing in North London!
At the biggest climbing centre in North London, there are 450 routes over 95 lines set across 1000 square metres of wall offering top-roping, lead climbing and bouldering on a wide range of slabs, cracks, overhangs, off-widths and chimneys - there really is something to suit every level of climbing ability!
I've never climbed before, can I come along? YES- but contact the Event Leader (see below)!
Supervised sessions
If you're unsure whether you need to be signed in as a supervised climber or not, if you answer
NO
to any of the following three questions, then you will need to arrange to be supervised. If you can answer YES to all these questions, you can sign up to this event as an unsupervised climber:
1. Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
2. Can you tie yourself to the end of a rope using the correct knots?
3. Can you belay another climber correctly and confidently?
To come along, you will need to register via this event page, and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the centre when you arrive.
See below.
Also to make climbing more accessible, the Castle has kindly provided us with some group benefits:
If you are climbing with the group, tell the reception when paying for entry and you will get the concession rate. That's £11.50 instead of £16.50 for full price entry!
For those in need of financial support, we have access to some free entries. Speak to the Event Leader about how this works. We need to provide to the Castle some basic details (name, DoB, email) 48 hours before the session.
Tokens are available for free shoe or harness hire. We have two ODL harnesses that we can lend beginners climbing with the group- so get the free hire shoes!
NOTE: If you are climbing with us for the first time,
either as an experienced climber or beginner,
please send a note to the Event Leader
telling them about your experience and goals.
There is a limit to the number of beginners that we can accommodate at each session. Each beginner needs to be supervised so we  need to ensure there are enough experienced climbings to help you out. Climbing is great fun! It's a fab workout, in a social environment. Give it a go!
Can I just come along and boulder?
Absolutely! Most of us do roped climbing on these Tuesdays. If you prefer bouldering, you can sign yourself in and do it, as long as you can fill in the climbing centre's form correctly, watch their safety video and can answer the simple safety questions at reception on your first visit. Meet the group at the start; some others might be bouldering. And definitely come join us afterwards in the pub.
Participation Statement
IMPORTANT! - Participation Statement
Before attending an OutdoorLads event, you MUST complete this
Participation Statement
,
in addition
to booking your event space. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend. Don't forget to register onto the event too!
Please note that every person participating should be aware of (and accept) that those members perceived as ‘in charge’ or leading the event are not necessarily qualified, do not need to be qualified, and are not regarded by OutdoorLads, or themselves as ‘technical experts’ but are amateur climbers with some experience and who are happy to impart their knowledge. Any advice given should be considered with this in mind by the recipient.
All those attending the event must also be aware of the centre's own terms and conditions of participation and abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre’s staff. Everyone must also take responsibility for their own safety while participating in Indoor climbing events.
Anyone with COVID-19 symptoms, even if they are extremely mild, or who has recently tested positive for Covid-19, is asked not to attend.
Can't make this event?
We run weekly climbing and bouldering events in the South East, so why not check out what's coming up near you here:
http://outdoorlads.events/SouthEastIndoorClimbing
. Alternatively, stay updated on upcoming events using the social media channels below:
Telegram
(Climbing and bouldering only):
OutdoorLads (SE) Climbing
Facebook:
http://fb.com/OutdoorLadsSouthEast
Twitter:
@OdlSouthEast
Difficulty & Distance: With top-rope and lead climbs at every grade from complete beginner to seasoned pro, you decide how hard it gets!

Title: Goyt Valley and Shining Tor
Summary:
The County of Cheshire is not so flat, join us for a walk along the Eastern Border of Cheshire where it meets Derbyshire
Event Details
We start with a descent into the Goyt Valley passing through the grounds of Errwood Hall, abandoned in the 1930's due to the construction of Fernilee Reservoir by Stockport Water Company. Whilst the hall was partially demolished, much of the ruins remain along with much evidence of the gardens.
As we climb away from the Hall,we get fine views of the more recently constructed Errwood Reservoir  before ascending the eastern flank of Shining Tor. At 559m Shining Tor is the highest point in Cheshire and offers extensive views south to Shropshire and west across Cheshire to North Wales should the weather be favourable.
The Route back follows the Ridge and is mainly paved and takes in the 2nd highest Peak in Cheshire, Cat's Tor 519m.
Are you new to OutdoorLads and considering your first event?
Have a look at this link, hopefully it will help:
https://www.outdoorlads.com/my-first-event
Don’t worry if the event is full.
Do
sign up and join the waiting list.
Often those on the main list cancel nearer the time.
There is a very high chance you will still get a place
All photos taken by the event leader
Difficulty & Distance: 12 km (7.5 miles), 350 m ascent

Title: Online Board Games

An evening of board games and good company.
Games that seem to be favourites include Azul, Solo, Saboteur, Just One, Next Station: London, Perfect Words, Concept, King of Tokyo, Rail Road Ink, Coloretto and Exploding Kittens
Ideas for new games are more than welcome!
You will be using Zoom to chat and encourage each other as we all try to win.

Title: NOTTINGHAM Indoor Climbing – THURSDAY – Beginners Welcome
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads at Nottingham Climbing Centre
Climbing evenings are held regularly and we tend to go to the local pub – The Lion for refreshments and a social gathering afterwards where they have a wide variety of beverages both alcoholic and non-alcoholic.
NOTE: If you are climbing with us for the first time
, either as an experienced climber or beginner, please send a note to the
Event Leader
telling them about your experience and goals. There is a limit to the number of beginners that we can accommodate at each session. Each beginner needs to be supervised so we need to ensure there are enough experienced climbers to help you out. Climbing is great fun! It's a fab workout, in a social environment, and anyone can do it! Give it a go!
Nottingham Climbing Centre
Nottingham Climbing Centre is equipped with walls and routes to suit all skill levels and groups of climbers, whether you are a novice looking to try climbing for the first time, or an experienced lead climber, you’ll find an area to challenge you. With 28 Top Ropes routes available as well as 24 Lines of Lead climbing for the more advanced individuals. In addition, 6 auto-belays are available, so there is always the opportunity to climb, even if the numbers don’t match up. The available bouldering walls also provide that extra physical and mental challenge for those looking for something slightly different from rope work. Both Bouldering and Rope Climbing routes range from 4a – 8a.
I'm new to Climbing - can I come along?
If you've never climbed before or need a refresher, the leader will sign you into the climbing centre as a
supervised climber
so that you can come and give it a try (it can be helpful to message the leader to let them know). If you enjoy your climbing experience, and would like to come climbing more regularly, we will also happily show you the ropes and teach you everything you need to know to climb safely.
Do I need to be Supervised as a Climber?
If you answer
NO
to any of the following three questions, then you will need to arrange to be supervised. If you can answer YES to all these questions, you can sign up to this event as normal:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie yourself to the end of a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly and confidently?
To come along, you will need to register via this event page and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the climbing centre when you arrive, please see their
website
for up-to-date prices. We ask that all members sign up through the event page to make sure the event leader has all information of the members attending.
To climb at Nottingham Climbing Centre you will need to:
-     Complete a climbing waiver for the centre (please arrive early to do this the first time, or better still complete it online before you arrive)
-     Pay the Lifetime Registration Fee - £6.00
-     Pay an Entry Fee directly to the climbing centre - £9.50 (ensure you mention ODL)
-     Hire shoes (if you don’t have your own) - £3.50*
-     Hire a harness (again, if you don’t have your own) - £3.50*
-     Hire shoes and harness - £6.00*
*Equipment hire charges will be waived for your first visit to the centre!
Can I just come along and boulder?
Absolutely! Most of us do roped climbing, but if you prefer bouldering, you can sign yourself in and do it, as long as you can fill in the climbing centre's form correctly, watch their
safety video
and can answer the simple safety questions at reception on your first visit. Meet the group at the start; some others might be bouldering. We will make sure we come and find you when we have our tea break!
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
IMPORTANT! - Participation Statement
You MUST complete a
Participation Statement
, in addition to booking your event space before attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Anyone with COVID-19 symptoms, even if they are extremely mild, or who has recently tested positive for Covid-19, is asked not to attend.
Photos:
All images supplied by event leaders and used by OutdoorLads with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Beginners welcome.

Title: Sky high social over Surrey
Summary:
Treat yourself - go on, you deserve it - and join fellow members for a chilled midweek dinner and drinks at the
Loft Sky Bar and OXBO Restaurant
in Woking. Some say this is the best way to see Woking (er, high above it).
Please feel free to gather for pre-dinner drinks on the 22nd floor at the Loft Sky Bar -
Gallery
- around sunset time. The main event is dinner on the 21st floor of OXBO
Restaurant
with its night views.
Let’s share stories of recent walks and events, and welcome new members in a relaxed environment.
To see all the walking events in the southeast, please click this
link
.
Don't waste that space!
We’re booked in for dinner and, if you can make it, pre-dinner drinks at these venues.  Although I appreciate there may be last minute changes, please only book if you know you can make it. If your plans change, please free up the space for someone else.
New Members
New members are very welcome. Please message me if you have any questions or concerns before the evening. Whilst we are a very open and welcoming group, if you wish, we may be able to organise an existing member to buddy up with you before or on the day.
Again, “no boots required” and no dogs are permitted.
Images courtesy of ODL leader
Jean-Pierre Noel
. Plus mine and “Cocktails” image from Pexels - acknowledgement Ahmad Syahrir.
Difficulty & Distance: Eat, drink and (possibly) be merry

Title: A Saturday South Bank Stroll
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for a mud-free stroll along London's historic South Bank. Starting at Waterloo Station, we'll follow the river eastwards as far as Tower Bridge, then cross over to finish at Tower Hill tube station.
The linear walk will include a long lunch stop at the fascinating Tate Modern art gallery, giving an opportunity to explore the extensive collections. Entry to Tate Modern and most of the exhibits is free of charge.
The sights:
Waterloo Station
: This is the London terminus for the South Western railway and services to Portsmouth, Bournemouth, Weymouth & Exeter along with south London commuter services. It is the largest station in Britain, has the most platforms (24), and is the second busiest. First built in 1848, it was reconstructed in 1922 and again in the 1990s to provide Eurostar services.
National Windrush Monument
: Bronze statue by Basil Watson unveiled in 2022 to commemorate the British Afro-Caribbean people to came to Britain on the Empire Windrush in 1948.
Jubilee Gardens
: This was the site of the Dome of Discovery & the Skylon at the 1951 Festival of Britain. It was created in 1977 and redeveloped in 2012. It is surrounded by County Hall, the London Eye & the Shell Centre. It includes a memorial to the British members of the International Brigades who fought on the Republican side in the Spanish Civil War.
Southbank Centre
: This comprises the Royal Festival Hall (the only surviving structure from the Festival of Britain), the Queen Elizabeth Hall, Purcell Room & Hayward Gallery. It is the largest centre for the arts in Britain. Underneath is a large undercroft which is feted as the birthplace of British skateboarding.
National Theatre
: The theatre was founded in 1963 by Laurence Olivier and was originally based at The Old Vic in south London, until its new permanent home on the South Bank was opened in 1976. The building is Grade II* listed, and is seen as a masterpiece of brutalist architecture. It contains three theatre spaces - the Olivier, Lyttelton & Dorfman.
Oxo Tower
: The tower was originally part of a huge cold store built by Lemco, the manufacturers of Oxo stock cubes, in 1928-9. When permission was refused for illuminated advertising signs on a tower, Lemco build the Oxo name into the windows on the four sides.
Tate Modern
: Converted from the former Bankside power station, Tate Modern houses the UK's national collection of modern & contemporary art. When the power station closed in 1981, the building was under threat of demolition until it was chosen as the new home for Tate Modern in 1994. The gallery was opened in 2000, with a 10-storey extension, the Blavatnik Building, following in 2016. It has around 4 million visitors a year.
Shakespeare's Globe
: This is a faithful reconstruction of The Globe theatre built 250 yards away in 1599. It was the brain-child of the American film director Sam Wanamaker, who fought for over 20 years to get a replica Elizabethan open-air theatre built in London. It opened in 1997, and stages Shakespeare plays during the summer months to a capacity of 1,400.
The Clink Prison Museum
: This recreates the conditions of The Clink, a prison which operated nearby under the control of the Bishops of Winchester between 1144 & 1780.
Winchester Palace: This was the townhouse of the Bishops of Winchester from 1136 until its destruction by fire in 1814. Today, the west gable end with its rose window survive as a scheduled ancient monument.
The Golden Hinde
: Not Sir Francis Drake's famous ship of 1577, but a full-sized 1973 replica built by traditional methods at Appledore in Devon. Like the original, she has circumnavigated the world, but since 1996 has been dry-docked at St Mary Overie Dock.
Southwark Cathedral
: There has been a church on this site for 1,000 years, with the present structure being built between 1220 & 1420 and reconstructed in the 19th century. It was a priory church till the dissolution of the monasteries in 1538, then a parish church, before being raised to cathedral status in 1905 with the creation of the new diocese of Southwark.
Hay's Galleria
: Constructed its present form as Hay's Wharf in 1861, it has survived wartime bombing and post-war disuse to become, in 1987, an office & retail complex.
HMS Belfast
: A Town-class light cruiser, she was launched in 1938 and served on the Arctic convoys, the Battle of North Cape (1943), the D-Day landings, and the Korean War. After decommissioning, she became a museum ship and is now a part of the Imperial War Museum.
Tower Bridge:
This is a combined bascule & suspension bridge, which, since its completion in 1894, has become one of the most iconic sights in the capital. Grade I listed, it still carries 40,000 vehicles a day.
Tower of London
: Begun in 1078 by William the Conqueror and largely complete by 1285, the Tower has served for nearly 1,000 years as a palace, fortress, prison, armoury, treasury and even a menagerie. It is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most popular visitor attractions in Britain.
Roman Wall:
Just by the entrance to Tower Hill tube station stands one of the few remaining sections of the wall that once surrounded Roman London. Most of the wall was demolished in the 18th & 19th centuries, but a few fragments have survived, either free-standing or as part of other buildings.
Dogs
Only guide/assistance dogs are allowed inside Tate Modern, making the walk unsuitable for ordinary dogs unless you are prepared to forego this part of the event.
Is this your first ODL event?
Attending your first event with OutdoorLads might feel daunting. What will happen, who will be there, and what can you expect? We know that new members in particular like to know in advance more about what an OutdoorLads event will be like.
If this is your first ODL event, you should check out the information designed specifically for you on the
My First Event
page on the ODL website
.
If you have any other questions you can send a message to the leader.
Photos
: Tate Modern (main) / The Shard / Windrush Monument (meeting point) / London Eye / Southbank Centre / National Theatre / Oxo Tower / Turbine Hall, Tate Modern / St Paul's from Tate Modern / Shakespeare's Globe / Clink Prison Museum / Winchester Palace / The Golden Hinde / Southwark Cathedral / Hays Galleria / HMS Belfast / Tower Bridge / White Tower, Tower of London / Roman Wall, Tower Hill.
All photos taken by leader 19th January 2026 and permission given to OutdoorLads for use.
Difficulty & Distance: Distance is 5.7km/3.5 miles, vertical ascent 78m/250 feet. This is a pretty much level route along urban pavements/paths.

Title: Pole Dancing Taster Session
Summary:
Are you the kind of person to seize the pole in Popworld and want to learn how to impress, or just want to try something new?
OutdoorLads have partnered with local aerialist and acrobatics organisation Cloud Aerial Arts for an exclusive taster session for members to learn pole-dancing with professionals.
Cloud Aerial Arts host classes at their studio in Piccadilly in Manchester, and welcome brand new beginners through to advanced level acrobats, aerialists and yogis. Their teachers are the most skilled and knowledgeable in the North West and pride themselves on promoting fitness in an inclusive space.
You can learn more about Cloud Aerial Arts and other available sessions via their official website:
www.cloudaerialarts.co.uk
This taster session will cost
£12.00
per member and will be
exclusive to OutdoorLads members
.
See you on the pole!
Photo credit: nialljohnson96
Difficulty & Distance: This will be a physically active session but aims to accommodate all sporting abilities.

Title: BIRMINGHAM Indoor Climbing - MONDAY - Beginners
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for an evening of indoor climbing & bouldering at Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre.
*** BEGINNER (supervised) events are offered every two weeks ***
If you have never climbed before (or need a refresher on the basics), then this BEGINNERS EVENT is ideal for you! I will happily show you the ropes & teach you everything you need to know to climb safely!
Event pages are split into
BEGINNER & EXPERIENCED.
Please ensure you sign up to the correct event as I can only supervise two beginners at once.
This event is for beginner climbers (those needing to be supervised) only!
If you are competent with how to tie in & belay (safely & confidently), then you will need to
sign up to the accompanying experienced (independent climber) event
instead.
Bouldering
- Whilst most of us do roped climbing, if you prefer to do bouldering, you can sign yourself in & go bouldering (unsupervised) instead of, or as well as, roped climbing. Please meet the leader & the group at the start though; some others might wish to do bouldering too!
Please note that we will not teach lead climbing or lead belaying on this event -
we would suggest having some
lessons in Lead Climbing
by a qualified member of staff if this is something you're interested in pursuing!
If the event is full, please join the waiting list as you may be able to get a space closer to the event date.
If you are subsequently unable to attend, please cancel off the event. Spaces for beginners are limited & 'no-shows' are frustrating for the leader & other attendees.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.
Climbing
- Unlike Indoor Bouldering there is a certain amount of skill to be mastered, such as tying in knots & belaying a partner, as well as the climbs being higher than in bouldering. If you are new to climbing (or would like a refresher), there are plenty of top-rope routes to choose from after learning the essential climbing & safety techniques with one of our friendly, experienced climbing leaders.
Bouldering
- Instead of tackling long high routes, the 'problems' (as they are referred to) are shorter & focus on technique, balance, body positioning & sometimes power. With the different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, so it’s excellent (but not necessarily easier) for newcomers.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
has more than 75 lines with over 300 routes, set through some spectacular ground including its notorious 'stalactite'. It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.
You MUST register via this event page before coming to the centre!
To climb, you will need to:
Complete a
Registration Form
(please arrive early to do this in-person the first time) & pay a Registration Fee:
Annual Registration
is
£5
or
Day Registration
is
£3
Pay an
Entry Fee
directly to the climbing centre:
Standard Entry
is
£12.50
&
Bouldering Only
is
£8.50.
Hire
climbing shoes (
£3.50
) & a climbing harness (
£3.50
) if you don't own your own.
Please see Redpoint's
website
for current prices & note that prices are subject to change.
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
PLEASE NOTE:
All those attending the event must also be aware of the climbing centre's own terms & conditions of participation & abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre's staff.
Photos:
taken & used with permission of
W. Allaway, D. Hanley
&
K. Jones.
Difficulty & Distance: This event is for BEGINNER (supervised) climbers only!!!

Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.

Title: Wick and Dyrham
Summary:
Join Andrew for a walk around Wick, Doynton, Hinton and Dyrham. The walk is easily accessed from the M4 and for those coming from Bristol, Bath and the surrounding area. We will be walking on the established Monarch's Way and Cotswold Way for part of the walk as well as passing through some beautiful villages and skirting around the edge of the Golden Valley Nature Reserve. There will be an optional pub stop at the end of the walk.
Photos taken by ODL members MEW and PL1957 and permission is granted to OutdoorLads for further use.
Dogs
are welcome to join us on this event but we do ask the following:
Please appreciate the fact that not everyone is a dog owner or lover- especially when we stop to eat
Please ensure you adhere to the Countryside Code at all times - see
(Keeping Dogs Under Effective Control)
If your dog is uncontrolled and strays in open land frightening other animals or livestock, the leader is supported by the OutdoorLads board of trustees to ask you to leave the event as this is not acceptable behaviour
We cannot guarantee that this route is dog friendly - there may be styles to carry your dog across.
Your dog needs to have the stamina to keep up with the group. This may be an issue on hot days.
Difficulty & Distance: 10.5 miles in about 6 hours inc breaks

Title: Top o' th' Calder. Todmorden.
Summary:
We will explore the upper extreme of the Calder Valley between Todmorden and Cliviger.
The infamous River Calder ("violent water") is mostly a culverted stream at this stage of its life.
We will pass close to its source at Heald Moor (the source two river Calders!).
The valley here is at its steepest, bleakest, quietest and remotest. It has its own unique beauty in comparison to further down the catchment.
We will have hills, great views and water! The walk is approximately 10 miles long with a 580 meter total ascent
We will call at The Bridestones, approximately 430m above sea level. They were formerly the abode of druids and the site of ritualistic and sacrificial ceremonies. It was probably named after Bridia, a Brigantes deity. Legend also suggests weddings took place on the moor giving the "Great Bride Stone" and smaller "Groom Stone" their name.
We will follow the Calder way To Pudsey Clough and straddle the Lancashire borders before heading up and along the opposite side of the valley by Dobroyd Castle, an important, historic building built in 1866 and continue back to Todmorden.
This is a dog friendly walk, so well behaved dogs welcome. There are a few stiles on a small section, so bigger dogs might need extra hands.
We will finish in The Golden Lion for a great selection of beers and Thai food.
Image / photo credits:
All leader's own images - OutdoorLads has permission to use and them.
If the event is fully booked:
please
join the waiting list as people frequently drop out during the week before an event and you are likely to get a place on the walk.

Title: Neilston and Howwood Loop
Summary:
Join us for a joint cycle with
Out Velo
- a short (37 mile) winter ride from Glasgow into the Renfrewshire countryside.
Outward route through Newton Mearns to Malletsheugh, cross-country to Neilston before climbing over to Howwood.
Return route via Johnstone and Paisley.
We should be finished by early afternoon, but bring lights just in case.
Ride is very weather dependent - if the roads are snowy or icy we'll reschedule it for another date.
Route:-
https://ridewithgps.com/routes/53398704
https://www.strava.com/routes/3429013927398464314
https://www.komoot.com/tour/2698827227
The pace of this ride will be typically 18-20 km/h and is best suited to road bikes, although riders on gravel bikes should also manage OK, particularly on the sections of cycle path.
Photos
: AI Generated and free for others to use.

chat
and

groups and bookmark our upcoming events list via our
Scottish Calendar
.

Title: Miles of Marbury
Summary:
Hi everyone,
Come and join me for a relaxed, easy circular walk in the beautiful Marbury area.
We head to Marbury to enjoy the big views from the top of the hill, and a gentle stroll along the canal, through several open fields, and around Marbury Big Mere Lake. The walk will finish at Marbury Church.
This easy, casual leisure walk is ideal if you’re new to OutdoorLads, or if you’re simply looking to meet new guys and make friends in a relaxed setting.
We’ll stop at the Willeymoor Lock Tavern for lunch, then finish back at the car park, with the option of a refreshing drink or meal at the pub afterwards.
Distance:
10 km (6 miles)
Dogs:
Well-behaved, socialised, and fully under-control dogs are welcome. Dogs must be kept on a lead where signposted and whenever we are near sheep or livestock.
New Members:
Please feel free to sign up to this as your first OutdoorLads event. If you have any questions, don’t hesitate to message me, or visit the “My First Event” section under “About Us”.
https://www.outdoorlads.com/my-first-event
If the event is fully booked, please join the waiting list, as places often become available in the week leading up to the walk.
Image/Photo Credits:
All images are the event leader’s own and are shared with permission for OutdoorLads to use and reuse.
Difficulty & Distance: Mainly  flat, with a small number of gentle hills

Title: A Springtime Social in Bolton - 2026
Summary:
Come and join OutdoorLads for a springtime
Saturday
evening stroll in Bolton for our vibrant
springtime social !
We will be celebrating springtime by visiting
some of the finest brew houses
, including
Ye Olde Man and Scythe
, which is thought to have been built prior to 1251 and is well renowned for its hauntings and spooky goings-on. Ye Olde Man and Scythe is full of character and has a lovely atmosphere and some fantastic regular live bands !
We will then explore the area in more detail and enjoy the fun and relaxing atmosphere. There will be plenty of opportunity for a nice ale, some nibbles, and the chance to throw some shapes on the dancefloor for those who wish to stay on a bit later.
Socials are great events for both new and existing members. If you are in any way uncertain about joining OutdoorLads, are concerned about fitness/ability, or whether OutdoorLads is for you, then please come along. Give us a go, have a drink with us and see why members have made friends through OutdoorLads. It is also a great opportunity to chat about upcoming events in a friendly environment.
Smart/casual dress code. Please no shorts or trackies !
Transport:
For easy access to/from Manchester and surrounding areas, the train and bus station/interchange is located in the town centre and is only a few minutes walk to the meeting point.
For more info, click
here...(https://tfgm.com/)
Photos taken by Growler, with permission for OutdoorLads to reuse.
Your First OutdoorLads Event?
We know that new members in particular like to know in advance more about what an OutdoorLads event will be like.
If this is your first OutdoorLads event, you should check out the information designed specifically for you on the
My First Event
page on the OutdoorLads website.
Waitlist
: If this event is fully booked and you want to attend, just add yourself to the waitlist, because places inevitably become available closer to the date.
Difficulty & Distance: Relax and enjoy

Title: Explore Wales’ Largest Ancient Woodland (located between Bristol and Cardiff)
Summary:
Going through mixed woodland and seeing lots of bluebells, we will pass the highest point in Wentwood (309m) on our way to the  Curley Oak (close to the most recent (1996) execution), then to the Foresters Oaks, where twice yearly Law Courts were held, with the last offender hanged in 1829.
We will then go past the Wentwood Reservoir and up to the summit of Gray Hill (273m) where we will find a Megalithic alignment of standing stones, stone circle and  neolithic or Bronze age enclosure.
We will then head back to the car park via the “Five Lanes” crossing, where it is possible to head in 10 different directions, which was the scene of Gwent’s biggest ever illegal rave (3000 people, for 36 hours) in 2007.
The area is home to thousands of wildlife species and we may be lucky enough to spot wild deer.
Dogs:
Dogs under close control are welcome on this event, so long as owners are able to lift them over locked gates and high stiles.
Photo Credits
: All photos taken by Paul Ridealgh; permission is granted to OutdoorLads for further use.
Difficulty & Distance: 12km (7.5 miles) in 4.5 hours

Title: Ben Tirran via Lochs Brandy and Wharral
Summary:
A joint hill-walk with the Gay Outdoor Club
Join us for a rewarding day in the Angus Glens as we explore the high plateau above Glen Clova, taking in two beautiful corrie lochs on our way to the broad summit of
Ben Tirran
. This route blends dramatic scenery with steady, achievable climbing, making it a fantastic outing for walkers who enjoy big views, good company, and a sense of journey.
We begin in Glen Clova, following the well‑made path that rises steadily toward Loch Brandy, a classic corrie loch cradled beneath steep, sweeping slopes. After enjoying the loch’s amphitheatre-like setting, we continue upward onto the plateau, where the landscape opens out into wide, rolling moorland.
From here, we make a gentle ascent to the summit of the Corbett, Ben Tirran at 896m, a broad, quiet top with expansive views across the Angus hills and out toward the Cairngorms. Our descent leads us past the tranquil waters of Loch Wharral, a lesser‑known gem tucked into the hillside, before we re-join lower paths and return to Glen Clova.
We will follow the route described on
WalkHighlands
.
Dogs:
The walk is suitable for dogs, which must be kept under control at all times, particularly near livestock.
Photos:
Taken on a previous walk up Ben Tirran with GOC in December 2012

Title: A Trio of Reservoirs in the Springtime
Summary:
An invigorating springtime
SUNDAY
Spectacular Walking and Picnic Event !
Welcome to a Trio of Reservoir Walk! This OutdoorLads walk will take us on a refreshing springtime stroll around all three large reservoirs: Entwistle, Wayoh and Jumbles. A perfect way to end the week with a, 'good ol' "leg stretcher", and a chance to enjoy the fresh feeling of spring !
There will be a mixture of terrains starting with a relatively leisurely flat walk around Entwistle, before the more challenging Wayoh and Jumbles, being completed in one lengthy loop.
We will stop off for a while to rest and enjoy the views, before we head off for our picnic at Jumbles. There will also be extra coffee breaks and photo opportunities throughout the day.
The Jumbles Reservoir is a heavily modified, high alkalinity, shallow reservoir in North West England. It lies in Jumbles Country Park, in the valley of Bradshaw Brook, partly in the Metropolitan Borough of Bolton, Greater Manchester, and partly in Blackburn with Darwen, Lancashire
After passing the water plantation on Wayoh on our home stretch, we will walk along the hillside paths – uphill, before reaching the final stretch of the walk which takes us back via the ‘Strawbury Duck’ country inn, and down back to the car park. The Strawbury Duck is approx. 5-10 mins from the car park.
Please message the event leader if you have any questions prior to the event.
All photos taken by Growler, and with permission for use by OutdoorLads
Well-behaved, socialised and under-control dogs are welcome on this event.
Dogs must be kept on a lead whenever this is signposted and whenever we are in the vicinity of livestock, and at the event leader's request. It's a good idea to check what the route may be like with the event leader before booking to find out more about the potential suitability of the walk for dogs.

Title: Tar Lakes & Rushy Common Nature Reserve Leisure Walk
Summary:
Join us for a relaxed 4.5-mile circular leisure walk around
Rushy Common Nature Reserve and the Tar Lakes,
a peaceful wetland landscape just outside Witney.
This easy-going route follows a network of flat gravel paths, paved sections and grassy tracks, looping around lakes, reedbeds and open meadows. Formerly a gravel extraction site, the area has been carefully restored and is now an important local nature reserve, with plenty of birdlife and open views.
We’ll walk at a sociable, steady pace, with time to chat and enjoy the surroundings. Around halfway through, we’ll stop at
The Bell Inn
in Ducklington for a drink stop.
Ducklington
is a traditional Oxfordshire village just outside Witney, making it a natural and welcoming halfway stop on our route. Food is entirely optional for individuals who wish to order, and the walk is planned to finish around 14:00.
The walking element itself is around two hours, with the pub stop making this a relaxed and social Sunday outing.
Dogs are welcome on this walk. Please ensure they are kept under control and are comfortable with walking in a group.
Difficulty & Distance: Distance is 4.5 miles. Terrain is  flat gravel paths, paved sections and grassy tracks.

Title: Bristol Board Games Sunday Social
Summary:
Join us for a Sunday afternoon socialising and playing games
Time to bring out your competitive side with a fun afternoon socialising with other Outdoorlads in Bristol's lovely Chance & Counters games cafe on Gloucester Road.
The cafe has over 850 new and old games to choose from so there should be something for everyone (although I could quite happily play UNO all day). To keep your game-playing energy up the café serves food, soft drinks and alcohol. We usually have lunch there and then start playing (but there's no obligation to eat, if you don't want to!).
I've booked a table at 1pm for eight for four hours. It's £8 each (paid to the cafe at the end of the session). We're a friendly bunch and it's always a good laugh. If you're new to Outdoorlads it's a great way to hang out with and get to know other members but in a cosy indoor setting.
[Photos downloaded from Pexels or taken by OutdoorLads Members and permission is granted to OutdoorLads for further use.]
Difficulty & Distance: As easy as the games we play

Title: BikeOut Festival 2026
Summary:
You are cordially invited to join the UKs first queer festival of the bicycle!  This will be run in conjunction with a whole range of other LGBT bike groups and is supported by Rapha and All In Racing.  There will be a whole range of cycles offered across the weekend - road and gravel are the name of the game.  There will also be some social events across the weekend, so it should be  a great way to get some miles in and meet some new people.  They plan to cater for most abilities - if you are used to cycling at least 40km on a road/gravel mix then there should be a ride for you.  If you are a super-fast road demon then that's no problem either - I am reliably informed there will be some advanced level rides too.
This event is being run by the BikeOut team, but OutdoorLads are an invited member group.  You will, however, have to register directly with the festival itself in order to attend the events: you can do so at this link
https://bikeout.cc/
You can also sign up here, on the outdoorlads website, so that we know who is coming from OutdoorLads and to help co-ordinate some social events over the course of the weekend.
There are cycles planned for both the Saturday and Sunday of the weekend.  There will also be an introductory, social event on the Friday night.
Bike hire is possible from AlpKit in Hathersage - please contact and arrange this early.
There are lots of accommodation options in the area -the bikeout website has details of them.  I, however, will be staying at North Lees campsite -
https://www.peakdistrict.gov.uk/visiting/things-to-do/camping/camping-northlees
This has both pods and camping pitches, and has the advantage of being the base for the rapha team for the weekend and also the planned site of a Saturday night pizza/bbq event.  The website says that you can take a campervan, but they don't have hard parking or electric hook-up - you need to park it in a standard parking space.
Difficulty & Distance: There will be a range of rides on offer, so you can choose from easier to harder

Title: Chirk & River Ceiriog Walk – Fall in Love with the Views!
Summary:
Don't worry if the event is full. Pop yourself on the waitlist and you'll get a place if someone drops out - People often change plans nearer the time and there's a high chance you'll get a place on the event.
Celebrate the weekend of love with a scenic ramble through the charming landscapes of Chirk and the River Ceiriog. This 6.5-mile circular route is the perfect way to share the outdoors with friends old and new—because nothing says "Valentine's" like falling head over heels for stunning scenery!
Our walk begins near Chirk and takes us through a mix of open pastures, peaceful woodland, and riverside paths. Expect a few steep slopes and stiles along the way.
We'll start by wandering through the historic grounds of Chirk Castle, a place that has stood the test of time—just like true love. From there, we join the legendary Offa's Dyke Path, where sweeping views of the Ceiriog Valley will make you stop and stare (and maybe snap a romantic selfie or two).
As we continue, the route leads us to the impressive Chirk Aqueduct and Viaduct, marvels of engineering that bridge more than just rivers—they connect landscapes and stories. And if that's not enough to make your heart flutter, the tranquil riverside paths and rolling pastures will surely do the trick.
This is Daniel’s assessment walk, so Daniel will be leading. Mark will be at the back, there purely for moral support (and assessment).
Image / photo credits:
- Chirk Castle, Wales, United Kingdom - Nick MacNeill - Licensed under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 2.0

- River Ceiriog - Eirian Evans - Licensed under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 2.0

Title: Ramble above Bury
Summary:
Join us for this dog friendly walk in Bury. We see the woods, hills and rivers of Bury. It's really amazing to have lovely countryside so close to a city. The walk is undulating so walking boots are a must. The walk is about
16km
long. You will be able to see the tall buildings of Manchester from our vantage point along with Ramsbottom and a small section of the river and woodland.
If the walk is full please join the waiting list as often a space becomes available
Image / photo credits:  All leader's own images - with permission for OutdoorLads to use and reuse.
Difficulty & Distance: Some smaller hills

Title: Leigh to Irlam -GM17
Summary:
This is stage 17 of 20 on the Greater Manchester Ringway, a 200 mile (322km) walking trail exploring all 10 boroughs of Greater Manchester. You can find out more about it
here
.
This section of the trail explores the Wigan and Salford Mosslands. This peaceful area, formerly used for peat extraction, has benefited from extensive regeneration and is home to more than 150 bird species, rare mammals, amphibians, dragonflies, butterflies and plants.
Highlights include:
Hope Carr Nature Reserve, which boasts a complex array of wetland habitats
Footpaths along the valley of the tranquil River Glaze (or Glazebrook)
Views of three historic country homes (Light Oaks Hall, Little Woolden Hall and Great Woolden Hall)
The 115-hectare Little Woolden Moss nature reserve, restored by Lancashire Wildlife Trust and now home to plant species such as sphagnum moss and cottongrass, birds of prey and ground-nesting birds, and animals such as the common lizard and bog bush cricket
Irlam Station, with its delightful linear park, restored signal box and friendly cafe.
Note that parts of the trail may be damp, muddy and slippery at any time of year and especially after periods of wet weather.
This is a linear walk
. See the options in the location details below.
Well-behaved, socialised and under-control dogs are welcome on this event.
Dogs must be kept on a lead whenever this is signposted and whenever we are in the vicinity of livestock, and at the event leader's request. It's a good idea to check what the route may be like with the event leader before booking to find out more about the potential suitability of the walk for dogs.
New Members

My First Event
page.
Photos by kvnmnc.
Difficulty & Distance: Around 17km (10.5 miles), 53m ascent

Title: A Tour of the Manchester Looplines - FEB ‘26
Summary:
Join Andy and OutdoorLads for a satisfying
Saturday
stretching of the legs along the historical Manchester railway lines.
From the start point we will make our way along the well maintained quality footpaths; taking in the captivating surrounding wildlife and woodlands.
We will pass through a variety of country parks, including Blackleach, Parr-Fold, and Worsley Woods. During the event there will be opportunities for a coffee break and lunch. There will be plenty of opportunities to stop for refreshments.
As usual, we will visit one of the local establishments for refreshments and a home-cooked meal after the walk for those wishing to do so.
Relaxed walk. Approximately 12 miles. Mainly flat.
Free Parking
Well-behaved, socialised and under-control dogs are welcome on this event.
Dogs must be kept on a lead whenever this is signposted and whenever we are in the vicinity of livestock, and at the event leader's request. It's a good idea to check what the route may be like with the event leader before booking to find out more about the potential suitability of the walk for dogs.
All photos taken by Growler
